bibl.title: Letter from D.S. Lamb to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 19, 1927

div1.p: Lamb describes his last encounters with Reed before he died.

div1.head: Letter from D.S. Lamb to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 19, 1927
div1.opener:
D. S. LAMB, M. D.
Popular Hill, Md.
October 19. 1927
Colonel J. R. Kean, i L. Y. A.
Dear Colonel Kean:
div1.p:
I have been much interested in
the report of the dedication of the
Walter Reed shrine at Bedroi, and I
notice that you took part in the cere-
monies. I recall also that you took part
in the Reed Memorial meeting of the
Medical Society of the District of Columbia
in December 1902, and as Editor of the
Washington Medical Annals, I published
an account of the meeting in January 1903

Knowing how interested you are
in whatever pertains to the life and his-
tory of Dr. Walter Reed, I want to say
that I believe - I am correct in the statement
that I saw him the last time he was at
the Medical Museum, where both he and I
were on duty. Dr. Borden had seen him
professionally on the 14th, of November (1902)
and made a diagnosis of appendicitis, but
the next, day Reed was better & less pain,
less tenderness, less tension, temperature
98.6, pulse 60, and Borden believed the
attack was about over.

Reed came to the museum, and late
in the afternoon he and I took a walk
thru the Museum Hall, talking of con-
ditions there and [?] changes like
I made; and he spoke of his illness,
the next day, was Sunday, and he
was not so well. I believe that the
Saturday, the 15th was his last day at the
Museum, and his talk with me, prob-
ably his last, or nearly his last
work there. The operation & appendectomy,
was on Monday the 17th, and he died on
the 23d.

It is a great pleasure to me to be able
to say that my relation with Dr. Reed were
always pleasant in the nearly ten
years of our association at the Museum.
